values:
Someone tell me I'm an idiot and that I shouldn't get another dog.  My apartment is small, I would have to pay additional pet rent for her...plus there's double food, double vet bills, double boarding bills...not to mention my family barely tolerates me bringing ONE dog when I go home for the holidays; I think with two I would end up sleeping outside in the backyard with them. 
 
But she's so CUTE.  Her name is Jasmine and she's seven--which means she will be considerably calmer than Muggle (who is a complete and total spaz, by the way).  She's potty-trained and has good house manners, is spayed and very healthy.  And she's FREE to a good home, which is why it's so tempting.  Muggle would love a companion/girlfriend and of course I would just love to have two pugs. 
 
But I'm nuts, right?  I don't NEED a second dog, right?  RIGHT???

To help with my awful anxiety, my new therapist (Dr. Lisa) suggested that I say/write this every day and keep it in close proximity so I can see it throughout the day.  She swears it will help.

  • I will let go of things that I can't control.
  • I am healthy, vital and strong.
  • There is nothing in the world that I can't handle.
  • All of my needs are met.
  • I am completely and utterly safe.
  • Every day I get a little bit stronger.

1. Whats harder to live without, chocolate or alcohol?  I don't know...probably chocolate because I'm not too fussed about alcohol.  Honestly, I'm not all that fussed about chocolate either, but I guess I like it more than alcohol.  Soda on the other hand...I'm not allowing myself to have it fo 30 days and it's very nearly killing me.
  2. Does the colour yellow remind you of anything?  Not really.
  3. Who most annoyed you last week?  Jim, perhaps.  Possibly Nicki.
  4. Do you have a cutesy romantic nickname for your partner (or previous partners)?  Just the typical 'honey' or 'baby'.  We're kinda boring.
  5. What is your favourite Stephen King movie?  Stand By Me or Shawshank Redemption.

What would make me ridiculously happy today?



*  A gorgeous, sunny day - check

*  Homemade chocolate-banana smoothies - check

*  Apartment searching with Lisa - check

*  Brand new Ed Hardy perfume - check

*  Letters in my mailbox from Sweden and Germany - check

*  Broccoli and potatoes with melty cheese....mmmmm - check

*  Knowing someone is in love with me - check

*  An hour-long walk with Muggle - check

*  Surviving my first day without Dr. Pepper - check

Today I begin my 30-days without soda campaign.  I will need all the support I can get to keep me from breaking down.



Ths is gonna suck.

1. Love at First Sight: Fact or Fiction?  Absolute fact.  It happened to me once, with my first boyfriend.  That was one of the greatest days of my life.

2. Fortune Telling: Fact or Fiction?  Depends on what sort of fortune telling it is.  Tarot and psychics...yes.  The Zoltan machine at the State Fair?  No.

3. Other Life: Fact or Fiction?  I don't know.  I think so, even though it creeps me out.

4. Afterlife: Fact or Fiction?  I certainly hope so.

5. Bigfoot: Fact or Fiction?  Uh...no.  Though one of my friends is a firm believer.  She has some very interesting and insane theories.
I have successfully been a vegetarian for 30 days.  I tried through Peta; they had a "Pledge to be Veg for 30 Days" so I gave it a try.  I really like and I've decided to stick with it.  Yay me.

1.  What do you see when you are looking out of the window closest to you?

              The apartment building next door and a man outside with his dog.

2.      Who was the last person coming into your room?

              Probably Nicole, my roommate

3.      What is the most predominant colour around you?

              Pink, of course

4.      What is right behind you?

              A wall...

5.      What is on today's calendar sheet?

              Cleaning, walking the dog, going to the gym...and I'll probably not do a one of them.

1. What song would you sing to your newborn child? (OR if you already had a child, which song did you sing to him/her?)
 
I've always found Beatles songs to be great lullabies.  The two that stand out the most would be 'Blackbird' and 'In My Life'. 
 
If I had a baby boy, I most definitely would sing him 'Beautiful Boy' by John Lennon.  Such a wonderful song! 

2. How do you think animals think? (i.e. in animal language, human language, etc.)
 
Oh, totally human language.  :)  At least, I've often imagined Muggle's thoughts...and he shows such human behavior sometimes that it seems only natural that he would think as a human as well. 

3. As a child, did you have a dream to make a difference in the world? Can you describe your dream?
 
When I was a child, I wanted to be a tractor.  So apparently not.

4. Do you believe in God/a Higher Being?
 
Without a doubt.

5. Do you believe in aliens?
 
I think so...I like the idea, anyhow.  Our universe is just so enormous, I find it really hard to believe that we're the only life form out there.

It's been a pretty good week for knocking some of these out...

26. Get a psychic reading - Done!  I got a reading from Steve McDonald yesterday at a psychic fair.  For the most part, I was pleased.  Well, maybe pleased isn't the right word...I found it surprisingly accurate.  Some of it was crap, but mostly it was pretty good.  I will post more on this later...

30. Discover 50 new bands (well, new to ME) (1/50) - Amanda gave me a lovely cd...and excuse me if I'm wrong, but are they called Qntal or is that the name of the disc?  Whatever it is, I likes it. 

35. Start a new savings account - I am TERRIBLE when it comes to saving money, so this is a big deal for me.  I started one up yesterday, and 10% of my checks will go into it.

73. Sign up to volunteer at least twice at www.volunteermatch.org (1/2) - I adopted a soldier in Iraq as penpal.  I have to send her weekly letters and monthly care packages.  

93. Gain 50 mutual livejournal friends (4/50) - I gained three this week!  Yay for new friends!

In progress

94. Make a list of 100 things I like about myself - This is harder than I thought...

1. How long ago did you join LJ?
I joined four or five years ago and have been active about half of that time.  I'm lazy. 

2. How did you find out about LJ?
Someone in ISPOL mentioned it once and a bunch of us joined.  I love journalling, so it was right up my alley.

3. If someone introduced you to LJ, is s/he still on your friends list?
Honestly, I can't remember exactly who it was...

4. Have you introduced anyone to LJ?
Yeah, a few people.  Don't think it lasted for any of them, though I really wish it had.

5. Is your LJ public or friends only, and why?
It's public.  I got nothing to hide.  :)

Last week I had a mole removed from my arm because it was 'suspicious'.  It had a slight discoloration, so they took it off and sent it away for a biopsy.  Since then, I've had to keep it bandaged up, only removing the bandaid long enough each day to clean the wound and put a new bandaid.  It itched like crazy for a few days, which I figured was due to just having some of my skin sliced off.  Just a few days ago it started to really hurt, and I was sure that the wound had become infected and I'd have to go back in to the doctor's office.  When I took the bandage off one morning, I noticed that I had a perfect, flaming red outline of a bandaid on my arm.  Two days later, it's still there.  A bit faded, but there just the same.  My skin feels almost burnt...and it hurts like a mofo.  I freaked out, of course, and called to speak to my doctor.  She says I'm allergic to latex and that from now on I should make sure that I keep it off my skin. 
 
That is FANTASTIC.  I've never been allergic to anything in my life; then in the last couple of years I develop allergies to cats and now latex.  I hate being old.

I'm surprised at how calm I have become.  I'm normally one of the most high-strung, panicky people in the universe, then suddenly I'm all...mellow.

Something changed in me; I think over the New Year.  Don't know what...or why...*shrugs*

It's rather weird.

Hooray!

Five...

1.   ... things you can't live without.
  • My gmail - I'm hopelessly addicted. 
  • My puppy -  I've survived 27 years without him, but now that he's in my life, I don't think I could survive without him.
  • My lipgloss -  I hate not having something on my lips.  That sounds a bit obscene, doesn't it?
  • My friends - They keep me sane.
  • Netflix - Sad, but true.
 
2.   ... of the best moments in your life.
  • Going to the Goblet of Fire premiere in London.  Nerdy, I know.  But damn, was that a good day.
  • The day I resigned at SHB.  Not because I hated it...well, I DID hate it at one point but I didn't at the time.  But it felt really good to finally be leaving all that negativity.  And on the vindictive side, it was good to be leaving when I was at a point that I was one of the better BA's and they would truly suffer if I left.
  • The day I met JJ.  Love at first sight sounds so corny, but for us, it truly happened.  I remember every detail of that entire day.
  • The first weekend Emily came to stay with me after I had moved to Kansas City.  I loved every second I spent with her.
  • Travelling to Orlando with Beth, Erin and Megan.  A great trip!
 
3.   ... celebrities you can't stand.
  • Britney Spears - I couldn't stand her even before she went nuts.
  • Jennifer Love Hewitt - Have you ever read her interviews?  She is the most vain person I have ever had the displeasure of reading about.  Ugh.
  • Lars Ulrich - He ruined Napster, the bastard.
  • Avril Lavigne - Her whole "I'm so punk" thing just bothers me...
  • Colin Farrell - ASSHOLE!!!!
 
4.   ... books you enjoy(ed) reading.
  • Harry Potter - I will enjoy reading them until the day I die.
  • Sideways Stories from Wayside School - This was always a favorite of mine in grade school.  I still crack up every time...
  • The Outlander - I fell in love with Jamie.
  • The Autobiography of Henry VIII - I have a bit of a crush on Henry...and there's a million books about him, but this is written from his point of view.  It's very interesting!
  • Romeo and Juliet - my very first experience with Shakespeare.
 
5.   ... items in your purse/backpack/on your desk.
  • A 20% off coupon for New York and Company
  • A checkbook with no checks in it
  • A newspaper clipping about Paul McCartney that I cut out for my aunt
  • My last fortune from Kin Lin:  "Keep an eye out for an opportunity soon to arrive."
  • A pack of double-A batteries

• My amazing office - I had an office at SHB as well, but I had to share it with another person.  Plus it wasn't an office so much as a small room with two cubicles in it.  I now have a real office with real furniture and real privacy if I need it.  It's nicely decorated with a pug calendar, a Harry Potter desk calendar, my own photography, and coming soon...a fish.  


  • Free soda - In each breakroom there is a giant cooler filled to the brim with every kind of soda imaginable.  FREE soda.  That is really going to get me into trouble.
  • R-E-S-P-E-C-T -  Something I never got at SHB, thanks to Ryan and Bat-Lady.  I feel very confident with this job and so far have been able to deliver whatever is asked for.  A rare feeling!
  • Traveling - I will get to do quite a bit of it.  Besides KS, we have offices in Denver, Phoenix, St. Joe (boring) and HUTCHINSON freakin' KANSAS.  The office in Hutchinson is miniscule...as in there's only two paralegals there and that's it.  But...if I wanted to make the trip down there to meet with them and do some training, they will pay for me to do it.  Getting paid to go home and visit my family sounds like a pretty good deal!  The LexisNexis offices are located in Chicago, so I'll get to do quite a bit more traveling there for various training sessions and whatnot.  
  • Getting paid what I'm worth - We didn't exactly get paid in peanuts at SHB, but it wasn't as high as BA's in most other firms.  I'm not a BA anymore; in fact I think I'm doing less than I did at SHB and getting paid a shit-ton more for it.
  • Working from home - I have the option to do this as much as I like, within reason.  I'll be given the software to load on my home computer so I have the ability to check my office email at home.  I worked at home for a brief period of time when I first moved to KC.  It definitely had its benefits, but I soon grew tired of it.  I was bored to death, plus I was in a new city and didn't know anyone except my cousin, who was barely around.  I longed to work in an office just for some human interaction.  Now that I'm in an office every day, there are many days when getting out of bed is just excruciating...and the thought of actually speaking to another person makes me want to die.  It will be nice to be able to hide at home on those days, without ever getting out of my pj's. 
  • Free parking - At last.  SHB had a parking garage, and we had to pay $65 a month to use it.  There was a free lot, but nearly a block away.  Plus it was uncovered and not in the best neighborhood in the world.  I'm in a fancy covered lot now with an underground tunnel leading to the building, in case of bad weather. 
  • Family environment - This has been quite an adjustment.  SHB was a ginormous corporation and I'm very much accustomed to just being one of the herd.  This is a much smaller firm and there's definitely a family feeling to it.  Most departments are made up of one or two people as opposed to a group of 15 or so.  At SHB, new people came in by the dozens...I'm surprised our ears weren't tagged.  Here I'm "THE new person".  I will remain the sole new person until someone else wanders in. 
  • Event planning - I LOVE planning parties and organizing events.  I'm such a nerd when it comes to this.  Now that I'm working in a Marketing department, that opportunity will present itself quite a bit.  We're currently planning a seminar for our female clients, and trying to come up with a fun theme.  We're going with the 'left brain, right brain' theme, I think-- 
  • Writing/Editing - Our department puts out the company newsletter each month.  I'll get my own column and will get to help out with editing.  Apparently most people aren't fond of editing, but the nerd in me loves it. 
  • No Ryan - Pretty much speaks for itself.  I am so thankful that I will never see that arrogant sumbitch again!

A friend sent this article to me:

Love Sick

Well, the medical profession has managed to come up
with a new mental illness. It is about being in
love--if you can believe that! The condition is
called, Limerence, and if you have it, you are called,
"limerent".

Basically, if you fall deeply in love, but become
obsessive-compulsive about it and react poorly, then
you are mentally ill with this condition and must be
treated!

Of course, every High School student in the country
has this disease! It's another way to pop a pill and
be medicated for life--because you can NEVER get well!
Your brain function is off.

So, all you love-sick puppies out there take heed. If
you come on too strong to your love interest, you will
be drugged!

According to Wikipedia, limerence has certain basic components:

  • Intrusive thinking about the limerent object.
  • Acute longing for reciprocation.
  • Some fleeting and transient relief from unrequited limerence through vivid imagining of action by the limerent object that means reciprocation.
  • Fear of rejection and unsettling shyness in the limerent object's presence.
  • Intensification through adversity.
  • Acute sensitivity to any act, thought, or condition that can be interpreted favorably, and an extraordinary ability to devise, fabricate, or invent "reasonable" explanations for why neutral actions are a sign of hidden passion in the limerent object.
  • A general intensity of feeling that leaves other concerns in the background.
  • A remarkable ability to emphasize what is truly admirable in the limerent object and to avoid dwelling on the negative or render it into another positive attribute.

It noted this as well:

Physical effects

The physiological correlations of limerence are heart palpitations, trembling, pallor, flushing, pupil dilation and general weakness. Awkwardness, stammering, shyness, and confusion predominate at the behavioral level. There is apprehension, nervousness, and anxiety due to terrible worry that any action may bring about disaster. Many of the commonly associated physiological reactions are the result of the limerent fear. Some people however may find that these effects come most strongly either immediately or some time after contact with the object of limerence, and this is accompanied with an acute feeling of ecstacy or despair, depending on the turn of events beforehand.



Shit!
Dammit, my dog is cute.

Anyone on flickr? I got a message today from one Demina Kira from BUZZfriends. According to her email, she's from a 'small web-design studio based in Saint-Petersburg, Russia', and they would like to know how much I'm willing to sell this photo for. It seems a bit shady to me for some reason...mainly because the photo is just ridiculously boring. I was bored at work one day and took a photo of my phone and desk. It's worthless, as you can see below: Upon closer inspection, I did notice the client billing numbers written on a piece of paper above my phone...I probably shouldn't have posted that. Oops.

After an 8-month hiatus, I have returned to LJ.  
 
Here's a brief recap of what's been going on in my absence:
 
*  I moved out of my own apartment and moved in with a roommate and her cat.  
*  I broke up with Chad in September.  This is a VERY, very good thing.
*  My car crapped out on me and needed $3400 worth of repairs.
*  I got a HORRENDOUS haircut which is finally growing out and not so bad anymore.
*  I spent the New Year's Eve in New York with <lj user=nickalee> and the love of my life.
*  I gave up on the love of my life...for good this time.  
*  I quit SHB after 7 looooong years.
*  I scored a sweet new job with a big raise.
*  I'm currently sitting in a hotel room in Chicago, drinking screwdrivers with <lj user=quietknitter> and Kevin.


Sadly, that's about it.  

The end.

Oscar Wilde once said "Anyone who lives within their means suffers from a lack of imagination."

Well, they also suffer from a lack of bills.  That would not be me.  I've gotten increasingly further in debt, and am finally taking steps to get out.  Today I was particularly pro-active.  

- I started a part-time job at Best Buy.  The main reason I wanted this job was so I could afford a $700 camera, which I don't really consider an EXPENSE,  but an INVESTMENT. 
- I cancelled my newspaper subscription.  I never read past the comics anyway.  
- I ordered MyFaves on my cellphone.  That way I get unlimited minutes for the top 5 people I call the most...which I think will cut my bill in half.
- My insurance agent gave me a written driving test that I have to fill out and mail in, and then I get 10% off my monthly premium.  It's a bit pathetic that I didn't know the majority of the answers, I really had to study the book.  But, I got through it.  Hooray.
Amanda said I should post this guy and have y'all caption it. I took this guy's picture at Gulf World in Panama City Beach last weekend. I think he hated us.

I'm sick. Last night a spider (or something else equally as creepy) chewed a trail from my armpit to my ankle. At first it itched, then it burned. Now my left arm is slightly numb and I have a fever. If I'm not feeling better in the morning, I'll go to the doctor. Ugh. Now for some pictures...

Equus! Me and Michelle, looking smug Clifford's Tower in York A big mess of English food Me A tree I ate my lunch under You can't have too many pictures of Big Ben

It was AMAZING, as I've already mentioned. Aside from the fact that Richard Griffiths was ill, and wasn't there. I was very disappointed by this; if I had seen him on the street I would have kicked him in the shins. I so wanted to see him! However, his replacement was equally as good, though he had to keep the script in front of him throughout most of the play. 

Anyhow, the stage was round, and the stage seating was directly above it. We had to go up a set of stairs at the back of the stage to get up there. You could tell these were just a temporary seating arrangement--they were a bit rickety and I had just a slight fear that they would go crashing onto the stage if there were too many people up there. It was tight and cramped, and we had to lean over a railing and look down. The railing was almost too high...I had my chin resting on arms and that didn't really work. Most of us there ended up with our chins right on the railing which worked great. However, the railing was carpeted, and when I left my chin was red and splotchy. It wasn't exactly comfortable, but the view was incredible. I was afraid we'd be watching everyone's backs the whole time, but that wasn't the case at all. We missed out on a few scenes that way, but there were also a few that faced us. There were only four props; big wooden columns that they just moved around as needed. They did a lot of fancy lighting tricks that added to it as well. 

The horses...I LOVED them. The men were dancers...and I don't mean they were up there doing pirouettes and jazz hands. Their movement was very choreographed and similar to a real horse; tossing their heads and stamping. They wore all brown and their 'shoes' were tall and metal, shaped like a hoof. They looked extremely uncomfortable! They kept their arms behind their backs and their heads down--on their heads they wore another metal contraption that was shaped like a horse head. The overall effect was actually kind of creepy--when they were on stage, I had a hard time taking my eyes off them. And considering who else was on the stage, that's really saying something! There were six 'stables' set up around the stage where the horses were kept, each with a metal grate on the floor in front of it. They would stand on the metal grates and as they moved or stamped, it would echo throughout the whole theater. The last scene with them was the most intense and by far the best scene in the play. The stables were dark and there was steam rising up out of the grates...the horses eyes were glowing and at first, that's all you could see through the mist as they walked through their stables. As Alan (Daniel) blinded each in turn, the light in their eyes would go out as they started thrashing about and tearing around the stage. 

As for the burning questions I'm sure you all have regarding the uh, controversial 'bits'...we had TOO good of a view of the girl--more than we wanted to see. Daniel was great. You could tell he was nervous, but who wouldn't be? Those of us on the stage saw WAY more than the audience as far as that was concerned. I was not disappointed. :)

Flat Stanley arrived from Chicago awhile ago. She's spent a lovely week with me in Kansas City and Hutchinson. She hasn't yet been on the Grand Tour of KC, as she's much too excited about her upcoming trip to London, but she's had a good time just the same.

She played in the fountains at Crown Center... Enjoyed the view from my office... Attended Pirates of Penzance and got to meet a (soon-to-be) famous actress... Ate space ice cream at the Kansas Cosmosphere in Hutchinson... And hung out with Muggle.

I love Aunt Janice's maniacal laughter.

I couldn't NOT post this. 

.....

I wish he wasn't clenching...

And it actually WAS this year.  There were no fights...no arguments...no tears.  Just everyone, all happy.  I almost didn't know what to do with myself.  It was nice just hanging out and being with everyone.  Emily and I spent one evening with Nicki's family, which may as well be my 2nd family.   Angie has a new baby, and it was so good to see her and play with her.  She was beautiful!  Chad flew into Hutchinson that Monday to spend the day with my family, and then flew me back to KC.  It's only an hour flight, which is MUCH more appealling than a 4-hour drive.  I think I would have really enjoyed the flight if I didn't have to pee so bad I could hardly move.  You can't exactly land a plane in a gas station parking lot for a pit stop...

I made an awesome casserole.  It was SO good, I nearly died.  I don't cook very often, so I'm really impressed when I make something and it turns out well.   It's broccoli, cheese, mushrooms, and a few other goodies.  But...bleh.  My stomach feels like its going to explode.  I should change its name to GASserole.  I think I'm going to die.  I just chugged half a bottle of Pepto in the hopes that my belly won't burst wide open.  I think I better lay down.  :/

I have five cats running around my apartment.  Okay, three--three are running around, two are standing on chairs yowling and spitting.  My own are very inhospitable.  The other three are 7 week old kittens that have been living in my grandparents backyard.  She's been feeding them, and now its getting too expensive for her to feed 8 cats.  She was going to call the pound, and I spazzed.  I hate the pound!  I had room for three kitties in my cat carrier, so I brought them home with me to take them somewhere that won't euthanize. 

These are beautiful little beasts...all three are grey and white.  We all bonded on the drive back to Kansas City.  Four hours is a long time, so we had plenty of time to talk and share Chicken McNuggets and fries.  There's one in particular that I've fallen completely in love with.  Tommy (I've named the trio Tom, Dick and Harry).  He is the sweetest little cat I have ever known.  I want to keep him!!  I'm moving into a house in Jan. or Feb, which isn't too far away...but I also wanted to get a dog, so I may as well just move to the zoo.  :/  Plus Iman has inflated into a permanent puffball, and Bowie's on the fridge and won't come down.  It's probably not a good idea to keep one.  But he's just so cute!!!

Look at their little faces!

  Tom and Dick

Tommy

Tom and Dick

Harry

I always buy flushable cat litter.  Always.  It's pretty handy.  Last weekend I went shopping, and they didn't have the brand of litter that I normally get, so I got an off-brand.  Which is not flushable.  I didn't think much of it at the time, I just went ahead and bought it.  

Last night I was cleaning the catbox, and scooped the kitty-business into the toilet.  Upon flushing, it made a funny little choking noise, and then filled and overflowed all over the floor.  There was soggy wet cat poo all over my bathroom.  

I don't think I like cats anymore.
My avatars never show up when I'm viewing my own page.  Are they invisible to yall, or am I just retarded?

I got my head peed on the other night.  My car needed fixin', so Amanda and 
I went over to a friends so he could work on it.  They happen to have a 
big dumb weimaraner named Misty.  Misty is very sweet and playful, and 
I enjoy her company.  However, Misty also has a tendency to pee 
everywhere when she gets excited.  And apparently she was very excited.  She 
has this little rubber toy she likes playing with, and every time I come 
over, she brings me this slobbery rubber thing so I'll throw it down 
the hall and she can chase it.  Much excitement.  I threw the toy.  She 
chased it.  Already bored with this game, I laid down on the couch.  
Misty comes running back all eager to play again.  She did a little 
dog-dance, then jumped up on the couch with me.  Suddenly the back of my head 
was strangely warm, so I sat up...and there was pee EVERYWHERE.  All 
over the couch, the dog, and my hair was dripping.  I didn't know what to 
do, so I just sat there and screamed until Amanda hauled me off the 
couch and into the bathroom so she could wash my hair in the sink.  I 
think I screamed during that whole process, too.   
Angela later told me this is called "Happy Pee".  I guess that's a good 
name, since everyone found it hilarious but me.  :/
